Lou Re has been retired for three years; he worked the last 33 years for Doubleday/Bertelsmann publishing in marketing. Fun time. He is still married to Mary-Jo for the last 41 years.  Time flies.  They have three kids and 5 grandkids.  He  spends his time playing softball year round, volunteering at the Guide Dog Foundation (where he recently met up with Tom Collins), taking courses locally, spending time putting around doing other small stuff, and also spending time as a gym rat. He's keeping busy.
Here's a picture of Lou and Mary-Jo.
Tom McNicholas biking in Napa country in January. (While those of us still in the Northeast are freezing and shoveling snow and ice.) Lookin' good, Tom.

Tom Collins, ThU 500, with two puppies, Chipper and Timothy; they're brothers, (notwithstanding the different color and body weight) and are both about eight months old in this picture taken in July of 2007 in Central Park...I had taken them with me from Florida to New York on my vacation. On this day we were doing 'subway training'. At about 13 months of age, both puppies were returned to the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind in Smithtown, NY for their formal guide dog training. Both boys were successfully graduated in June of 2008. Chipper is currently working in Philadelphia and Timothy is working in New Hampshire.

Tom is currently working with a dog named Vacca, sponsored by the Bridgehampton, NY Lions Club. Vacca is a Labradoodle and is going back to NY for his formal training in about three weeks. Here are Vacca and Tom.

The house corporation's annual meeting was held on June 30, 2007. Most members attended by proxy, but stalwart Al Theesfeld provided photographic evidence of the meeting (as well as the minutes). Here's the front of 36 Sidney place--looking in good shape.
Present at the meeting were:  Walt Lastig (ThU 338), John Martin (ThU 366), Alan Theesfeld (ThU 460), Russ Lowell (ThU 721), and Active Chimi Kadriu (ThU 838), not shown.
Being an official meeting, a stop at O'Keefe's was in order.
O'Keefe's has gone upscale since we were in school.

Roger Grice at Lambda Chi Headquarters in June 2007 to receive training for the rollout of Lambda Chi's True Brother initiative. The rollout will happen in July at the Leadership Seminar in Memphis. The purpose of the True Brother initiative is to return the fraternity to its value-based roots--the things that we all learned (and memorized while doing pushups) when we were in school. Headquarters is an amazing place--a living museum of Lambda Chi Alpha's (and Theta Kappa Nu's) history.

Linda and I vacationed with friends, the Benavides, and vitiated the Pueblo of Coquimatlan in Colima, Mexico for about 3 weeks in January. (also spent time in Mazatlan, Colima, and Manzanilo). We had a great time, and they party a lot harder than I ever experienced @ Lambda Chi--2 consecutive weeks beginning just before Christmas and ending the first week in January -- non stop!  The picture to the left is me standing in front of the central park in Comala, Mexico.  "Hi" to all, and retirement sure is a lot more fun than finals! All the best until our next reunion - Ed Johnston - ThU 475

On Sunday, April 1, 2007, there was a Rock 'n' Roll Reunion Concert at the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater at the corner of Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues. I had been to one of the first concerts that Alan Freed held there in 1957. I made the trek into Brooklyn to attend the reunion concert. It was great. Here's what the old Brooklyn Paramount looks like today--it's the gym for LIU.

img: img/UsToday/Concert Sign on the Brooklyn Paramount.jpg
description: Here's the announcement sign on the Flatbush Avenue side of the building
Here's the program card that they handed out. It's a replication of the ad that appeared in the NY Daily News. What a line-up of acts. What memories!
Here's the back of the handout with details and costs. I got a seat in the bleachers (the old balcony)--all that was left for the 2:30 show by the time I got around to ordering.
Here's a shot of the program finale. My camera does not do a great job of shooting long-range in the dark. I took a lot of shots during the concert, but most of them are too dark to be recognizable.

No trip to the Brooklyn Paramount (actually, no trip to Brooklyn) would be complete without a stop at Junior's--right across Flatbush Avenue from the old Brooklyn Paramount. I stopped there before the concert for lunch: hamburger, chocolate egg creme, and (of course) a slice of Junior's cheesecake. On the wall by the lunch counter is a shrine to Mary, the waitress who retired recently after 50 years of working at Junior's. That means she must have been there when we were at Poly. Does anyone recognize her?
